data.title: Add editor option to hide material/texture preview in inspector
data.body:
Hello, this is my first try to contribute to a open source project, any advices are welcome.
I have added two options for toggling material and texture preview located at editor settings, inspector section. The purpose is to save space in the inspector tag. 

Closes #6542

data.title: Can't build Godot for Android (from Windows)
data.body:
Using Windows 10 64-bit with [this script](https://gist.github.com/Calinou/44edbd5d9c4a2ac0dbc8f165b8b7f0ce) to compile. MinGW-w64 is installed as it seems to be required for compiling for Android, and is in PATH. Android SDK 23.0.3 is used, with latest Android NDK.

```
Compiling shared ==> platform\android\os_android.cpp
=====
arm-linux-androideabi-g++: error: /Foplatform\android\os_android.os: No such file or directory
arm-linux-androideabi-g++: error: /c: No such file or directory
arm-linux-androideabi-g++: error: /TP: No such file or directory
```

Visual Studio 2015 is also installed, if that matters, but it is not in PATH for building for Android (it used to work just fine this way).

data.title: convert charset to UTF-8 with BOM.
data.body:
convert charset to UTF-8 with BOM.
non-ASCII characters are problematic for orientals.

data.title: Prevents rand_from_seed from exceeding RANDOM_MAX
data.body: Even though the seed being returned had the most significant bit killed by & masking with Math::RANDOM_MAX, the value was already set in memory. Thus, calls that don't use the return value of the function (which is completely sane behavior, given that the function sets the pointer) can get a number larger than RANDOM_MAX.

data.title: Document default constructor of primitive math types
data.body: Primitive math types often have multiple constructors, but the default one is not listed. Also, some people read the docs first before writing code (especially with a scripting API), it can be misleading to hint there is no default constructor, leading them to not even try.

data.title: xorshift32 PRNG for Math::rand_from_seed()
data.body:
should fixes #1043

PRNG adapted from : http://excamera.com/sphinx/article-xorshift.html

~~TBH, i'm not sure the periodicity of this XorShift is actually~~ 2^31 - 1, 
~~neither if it is as well balanced than the original xorshift32.~~

edit : as long as the 32bits of `*seed` are not altered, the periodicity of this PRNG should remain 2^32 - 1.
If the 32nd bit of `*seed` is lost or altered between castings from C++ `rand_from_seed()` and GDscript `rand_seed()`, then, the actual periodicity can't be determined.

If some mathematicians wants to give a look at this, here is the official XorShift paper :
["Xorshift RNGs" by George Marsaglia](http://www.jstatsoft.org/v08/i14/paper)

data.title: Add Shape2D node
data.body:
The engine is already available CollisionPolygon2D and CollisionShape2D for draw invisible collision zones. The last allows you to assign simple forms to shape such as a square, circle, and so on... But only Polygon2D there to draw for only custom forms.
Why not include a node Shape2D, through which you can quickly create a visual form of squares, circles and lines? Currently to create a simple circle I must import the sprite, making sure it is large enough so that he had clear edge.

data.title: Make scripts and shaders embedded in .tscn be more readable and diffable
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Win 7 32 bit Pro; Linux Ubuntu 16.04 64 bit.
Godot 2.1 in both cases.
My project is stored in a Git repo (hosted on Bitbucket).

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The files are saved in a format that (1) doesn't let humans easily study them, nor (2) let automatic diff tools understand them.

Personally I think the .tscn file should be split up into a parent folder and individual files underneath it. Putting the entire scene with all the various GDScripts into one file is poor ux.

AND GOD HELP YOU WHEN THERE ARE MERGE CONFLICTS.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1) have a Godot project with GDScript files in it.
2) make changes.
Expected: to be able to see the individual diffs in a diff tool. Also to be able to ready or edit the file manually easily.
Actual: Things are not diffable because (1) too many things are stored in a single .tscn file; (2) whitespace inside GDScripts are saved as excape characters. So the diffs become entire giant chunks of entire GDScripts.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
See screen shot.
![saddiff](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/77176/19215705/2a2af892-8d5a-11e6-8cf5-1dc2a7907ccc.PNG)

data.title: Place child dialog contents under label in AcceptDialog
data.body:
Placing child dialog contents under label in AcceptDialog ensures, that custom text and FileDialog Path label do not overlap.

Fixes #6199.

data.title: Make node serial naming per-project and universal
data.body:
The editor setting `duplicate_node_name_num_separator` was nice for duplicate operations, but on other situtations when node name collisions could arise (create, instance and reparent) the behavior was inconsistent.

While duplication was honoring the separator setting and looking for non-colliding numbers from the number of the operated node, the other operations were always putting a white space between and trying to find an available number from one.

This PR makes every operation follow the same rules (separator-aware, counting from the number of the operated node) and also renames and moves the setting to become now per-project because:
- it's the easiest way of making every operation aware of the separator setting without adding a lot of conditional code for editor/non-editor situations and to make live editing already aware without making it more complex;
- name-number seprator pertains to the naming style chosen for a specific project.

Furthermore, some duplicated code is removed and the APIs are clearer.

This PR also fixes a bug where a reparented node would not get its original name back on undo if it had been changed to avoid collision.

data.title: Support bilinear bars in TextureProgress
data.body: Supporting bilinear bars in TextureProgress (bars that extend in both directions, eg. left and right, up and down, clockwise and counter-clockwise) would be handy, so that you can make such bars using only one node (instead of two currently).

data.title: Should I put the MIT license in my game created with godot?
data.body:
Hello.

I am not exactly sure if this is the right place to ask this question but let's ask:

Someone on this topic:
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/1635
Said this:

"I'm not a lawyer either but here's the thing.. MIT license states "The above copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in all copies or substantial portions of the Software." and because there is no definition of "software" it can be misinterpreted. Software can be defined as a set of machine instructions (which is binary file) meaning you're legally obligated to put a MIT copyright somewhere in the executable file. So mentioning of godot is not required, but copyright notice must be included somehow (not necessarily has to be rendered to the screen). But to play it safe - just include it in the credits and be done with it."

Is this true if it isn't true why isn't it true can you explain about it?

And also in Godotengine.org it says:
"Godot is completely free and open source under the very permissive MIT license. No strings attached, no royalties, nothing. Your game is yours, down to the last line of engine code."

I think if that thing is true this thing in Godotengine.org isn't true because I think that thing in Godotengine.org also means you are not forced to put anything in/with your game but if that thing is true I think it means you are forced to put something in/with your game.

I also asked this question in the Q/A of godotengine.org too.

Thank you.

data.title: Comments field on scenes and a panel for it on editor
data.body:
This is a feature request:

Since everything tends to be pure visual I think that could be nice to have a simple comment field as part of the scene file and the corresponding editing panel in the editor.

That way you will be able add scene description, some details or anything you need to say/remember about the scene being edited.

Something like:
![commentsection](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10215987/19213883/9c1a7aa8-8d4c-11e6-9d13-288c8c031a1e.png)

data.title: Issue #6296: When searching for control, checking if matrix is inversible
data.body: I have added check to viewport testing, if matrix is inversible. In general, if basis_determinant()== 0.0, one cannot inverse matrix and error is left. But when searching for control, basis_determinant()==0.0 implies, that control is not in scene. See https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/6296.

data.title: 'Save Branch as Scene' - the branch should immediately be replaced by freshly saved scn instance
data.body:
When you are saving a selected branch as scene, the scene you just saved should become an instance in your scene.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6776092/19212323/009d5b7e-8d4f-11e6-9527-c054aab0799a.png)

I am confident that majority of people using this feature would want to replace the saved scene into an instance such as this:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6776092/19212334/2650bae6-8d4f-11e6-952c-0809299b66bb.png)

Even if the user did not want to instance the scene, it is far easier to remove an instance than it is delete node, select parent node, open new instance, navigate to saved instance, and select it.

If it is changed to an instance by default, and you dont want the instance, you can just click on the instance icon and select "Discard Instancing".

Hoping this gets changed for the better :)

data.title: Better checks for Multiplayer API, prevent packet source spoofing.
data.body:
Fixes the following problems.

A malicious client was able to contact another peer faking its identity
(even looking like he was the server).

A malicious client was able to force other client disconnections by sending
bogus system packets to the server.

data.body:
Is it possible to implement a feature in Polygon2D, or maybe in math core with 2 vectorpoints in parameter to merge 2 polygons that overlap in only one?

data.title: World origin shifting for large open world games
data.body:
Hey Godot Developers,

I have a bit of a feature request for Godot engine. Currently I am working on a large scale multiplayer space sim with the Godot engine. I wont go into much detail about my game other than say it covers a very large area.

That said - I need the ability to shift the world origin on the X, Y and Z axis as needed.  Currently as it stands Unreal Engine 4 is the only engine that can do this out of the box. This feature would also need to work with the new High level networking API. 

Would it be possible to implement this feature? I want to make something that is amazing with Godot but I just need some help with some core features of the engine.

Thank you for your time,
HeadClot

data.title: Proposal for Godot to accept Bitcoin contributions
data.body:
Hi!

I like Godot and would like to contribute some bitcoin for helping develop more features. The Bitcoin community is quite big and I am sure there would be others who'd contribute too.

Accepting Bitcoin has pros and cons.

Pros:
- Accept donations from around the world
- Very fast and mobile (get money to developers, whichever country they're in)

Cons:
- Keeping bitcoins secure is not common knowledge
- Learning about the various wallets and signing up to exchanges is a significant barrier

Other considerations:
- Bitcoin can be volatile at times, though recently it has been less of an issue. If Godot were to accept Bitcoin contributions, would they be immediately converted to fiat (harder to set up) or converted semi-regularly?

I've been actively using bitcoins for over 5 years and am happy to help / advise if the developers, Juan Linietsky and Ariel Manzur would like to proceed.

I also have a secure hardware wallet capable of holding separate account Bitcoin funds if a custodian method is preferred.

data.title: Use int consistently instead of int32_t for Vectors
data.body:
I'm using the devkitARM toolchain to use Godot in 3DS homebrew. This problem arose, but was easy to fix.

There is no defined `Vector<int32_t>` and therefore any compiler/arch that would distinguish between `int` and `int32_t` will have problems. Another possible solution is to change all defined Vector methods to all use `int32_t`, but this is easier and I wasn't sure what core devs would think about that.

data.title: Throw an error when exporting a resource class
data.body:
As per requests in #6729 this is the patch that throws an error instead of allowing the behavior:
`export var tex = Texture`

The error will be:
"Exported constant not a type or resource"
I'm open to suggestion on better messages.

Fixes #6719 . Closes #6729

data.title: Allow exporting vars by specifing the resource class Fix #6719
data.body:
`export var tex = Texture` will now export a Resource variable of type `Texture` (initialized to null).
Fixes #6719 . Closes #6730

data.title: KinematicBody2D + CapsuleShape2D move problem with one way StaticBody2D
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7/Ubuntu 16.04 64bit - Godot v2.2alpha.custom.build (fixnum - 09/22)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
What happens: With the player character of the new platformer demo that uses `move_and_slide` (and a `CapsuleShape2D`), if you jump just on the corner of a one way platform (`StaticBody2D`), the player gets stuck (on Y axis) for a moment then is pushed down.

What was expected: If the kinematic controlled character that uses a capsule shape collider jumps to the corner of a one way `StaticBody2D`, it should either be pushed up or ignore the obstacle.

It can be reproduced with the old kinematic character controller too (the one from the demo) with a shorter effect, I was unable to reproduce it with a rectangle collision shape, is possible that the `CapsuleShape2D` has issues with `move` in this case.

**Steps to reproduce:**
-Load the new platformer demo OR the attached project.
-Jump and try to reach the border of a one way platform as shown in the animation below.
-Try again with other collision shapes on the player scene.

![onesidestuck](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10215987/19159106/98428ef2-8bc1-11e6-8af7-2ab280e3ba4e.gif)

**Link to minimal example project** :
Simplified new platformer demo with two controller scripts (Platformer demo and Kinematic Character demo).

[onesidebug.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/514191/onesidebug.zip)

PS: Credits to my little niece for the find.
